characters: A ROW OF SHOT GLASSES ARE SLOPPILY FILLED WITH TEQUILA.
THROUGH A SLIVER OF WIRE-GLASS IN THE DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nestled at the edge of 64.8 acres of rugged woodland. KID play on rope swings, timber slides and rugged wooden see- saws. MOTHERS and NANNIES sit and talk together on benche A young man, CECIL ACKERMAN, 24, pale skin, red hair, is watching from beyond the playground fence. His eyes follo the little girls, some of them no more than 6 years old, they swing to and fro. He sees a small girl, EMMA, 7, toss a ball. It goes throu the fence and rolls out onto the path. Emma looks to her NANNY, 19, but she is deep in conversation. Emma slips through a gap in the fence and goes after the ball. As sh bends to pick it up, she clumsily kicks it. The ball roll away down a sloping path into the woods and Emma goes aft it... Cecil looks at the Nanny. At the other Mothers. Nobody ha noticed Emma’s absence. Cecil pushes back from the fence casually walks away. EXT. FRANKLIN PARK —- EVENING Emma's ball bounces off the path and into the bushes. Emm follows it. Pushing though the foliage. She sees her ball and -- Cecil picks it up. Emma looks up at him. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Is this your ball? Emma takes a small step back. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Emma.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Emma. That’s a pretty name. Cecil holds the ball out to her...

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be afraid. Here. Come and take it. Emma takes a small step forward. She reaches for the bal Doesn't fully commit...

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I won’t bite, Emma. Emma takes another step toward him and AN OUT OF FOCUS FI appears behind Cecil. A HAMMER (wrapped in plastic) rises above him and -- EXT. CHILDREN’S PLAYGROUND - FRANKLIN PARK - EVENING Emma's SCREAM alerts the Mothers and Nannies. All bolt up Looking around. We FOCUS on Emma’s Nanny. Scanning the children...

dialogues.speaker: NANNY
dialogues.text: Emma! Where’s Emma?! Another SCREAM and Nanny vaults the fence and runs down t sloping path.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: EXT. FRANKLIN PARK —- EVENING Nanny bursts through the bushes and finds -- Emma just standing there. Unhurt. She has tears streaming down her face. Cecil is gone. Nanny drops to her knees an envelops the sobbing child as -- in the woods somewhere w HEAR a vehicle engine starting. Emma looks at the ball settling on the ground. A single drop of blood rolls down its plastic surface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of the surprisingly warm looking brick building. MITCH’S VOICE The defense would have you believe that circumstance is what put the accused in this court today. INT. COURTROOM — COURTROOM - DAY (A.D.A.) Assistant District Attorney MITCH BRODY, mid 30s stands before the Jury. He’s Boston born and raised but h softened the accent. There’s a slight scrappy edge to him A fighter.  JUDGE McKENNA, 60s, a stern looking woman, presides.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Honesty or, in the defendant's case, a lack of honesty - that’s why we're here today. Call it character. Call it backbone. Call it common decency. Everyone has a choice. (beat) Lack of education opportunities, a broken home, low employment rates are nothing but excuses to hide behind when you're deciding who you want to be in this world. (beat) Neither fate, nor society, put Francis Mulligan inside the house of Gloria Mitchell on the night of the fifteenth. Neither fate, nor society, told him to tie her up - shove a gun in her face - and take her belongings. That was his choice. Mitch looks at MULLIGAN, 25, Irish tats up each arm. Mulligan stares back with total disrespect.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The defense would have you walk in his client’s shoes. Well I have. I’m from Dorchester. (this gets people's attention) It’s a shit hole. Nobody’s saying it’s not. But that’s where I’m from - not who I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulligan looks down. Confronted by an alternate life.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s not the victim here. So, if you're going to put yourself in anyone’s shoes - put yourself in Gloria Mitchell’s. Mitch walks back to his seat and sits beside fellow A.D.A STUART KEMP, early 30s, doughy, not what you would call handsome.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Nice close, DeNiro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like that?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Not who I am? It was golden.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: The jury will adjourn to deliberate a verdict. Mitch, Stuart and the defense settle into their chairs to wait. A defense attorney leaves to take a call...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You got any snacks? I missed breakfast. Rachel’s on total bed rest for the last few days.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I told you, I’m on a diet.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You're telling me you don’t have one chocolate bar hidden in there. Mitch grabs Stuart’s briefcase and digs. Finds a Snickers bar. Grins “ah-ha!”. Stuart looks busted.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: That's for emergencies. In case my blood sugar drops. Mitch’s phone buzzes. Reads: “IT’S TIME!”

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s time. Oh, shit. I gotta go. Mitch puts down the Snicker’s bar and starts to stuff pap into his case...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: But the jury’s still out.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s a guilty verdict. Five years. Parole after two.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: One - Judge McKenna’s soft on the educationally challenged and nobody got shot.  Mitch picks up his case --

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: And two?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (smiles--) I don’t lose. (to Judge McKenna --) I’m sorry about this, your honor. I’m going to have to leave my esteemed associate to finish up. My wife just went into labor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Congratulations, counselor. You're free to go. Mitch turns to walk away -- then reaches back and snatche the Snicker’s bar.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s an emergency. Mitch hurries down the aisle toward the rear doors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch’s Escalade zooms into the tree-lined, suburban stre Kids skateboard and play ball. He turns up the driveway o pretty, but modest, two-story starter-home. INT. STUDY —- MITCH’S HOUSE - DAY A PHOTOGRAPH OF A SIX YEAR OLD MITCH AND HIS MA’ (on the wooden steps of a run-down house in Popes Hill) dominates shot. It’s oddly framed (they’re both too close to one ed like we're only seeing half a picture. It sits on a desk with other photos of Mitch and his wife. Through the wind we see Mitch’s car approach the garage. There is a groani CLUNK that shakes the house as the garage starts to open. INT. BEDROOM — DAY RACHEL BRODY, 29, crushes Mitch’s hand as she pushes. The MIDWIFE, late 50s, heavy German accent, urges her on. Spa medical equipment needed for a home birth stands beside t bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby is crowning. I can see the head. Keep pushing. Mitch kisses Rachel’s head...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You're doing great. Breath. Push....

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, push. Rachel crushes his hand...

dialogues.speaker: MIDWIFE
dialogues.text: I can see the shoulders. One more push.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: MIDWIFE
dialogues.text: One more.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You can do it. Rachel strains with all of her might, lets out a pained g and - the baby girl is out. Midwife clears her nose and mouth and then wraps the baby a blanket and hands her up to Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You did it. Oh, my God, I can’t believe it. Rachel holds her. Tears in her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hello, baby girl.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Let me take a picture.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, I’m a mess.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You look beautiful.  Mitch kisses her. Pulls out his iPhone and fires up the screen. He sees a text: “GUILTY. FIVE YEARS. I HATE YOU.” Mitch smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (to baby) I think clever daddy just won another case. Joe aims the iPhone at Rachel and the baby...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Smile. Rachel smiles. Click. Mitch likes the photo...

dialogues.speaker: MIDWIFE
dialogues.text: Mr. Brody, would you like to cut the cord? Midwife holds a pair of scissors out to Mitch. Mitch hesitates. Rachel laughs at his expression..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch is at the work-bench. He has a beer open. He’s assembling the first pieces of A BABY CRIB. He has a wall tools in front of him, each piece hanging on a hook. He takes down a screwdriver and we see there is a silhouette it drawn on the wall. A place for everything.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BOARDROOM —- DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE -— DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch, Stuart and the rest of the DA’s staff are crowded inside. All toast Mitch with a glass of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Limes are jammed on the edges and the tray is lifted and carried through the crowds. Sports play on flat-screens. Music pounds. The tray is put down on --

dialogues.speaker: A CORNER TABLE
dialogues.text: where Mitch is wearing an oversized pin that reads “Baby Daddy!” and is sitting with FRANK, STUART, and JOE.  Great friends who all went to law school together. Empty beer and shot glasses litter the table.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Another toast. STUART picks up a Tequila shot. The others follow suit...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m pretty toasted already. Stuart raises Mitch’s hand anyway...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: To the bastard who has it all. A beautiful wife, a great career --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Awesome friends.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: And now a perfect little girl. Mitch lets this soak in. He does have a good life.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: To me. They shoot the drinks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch is at the urinal. Swaying. Singing to himself. He washes his hands at the sink. His phone rings. Mitch wipe his hands and answers it.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is a collect call from an inmate at Concord Penitentiary. To accept this call press one. Mitch’s demeanor sobers. He clearly knows who it is. The door opens. Mitch kills the call...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey, Baby daddy. You okay? Frank approaches the urinal...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not going to hurl are you? Stu’ just got another round.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Bring it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. THE PAXTON TAP — NIGHT The streets are quiet. A light rain falls. Mitch, Frank, Joe and Stuart stagger out of the bar laughing. Frank cla Mitch on the back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I hope you’re not driving, counselor.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Got the cab number right here. Mitch shows his iPhone. Frank hugs him...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Be well, man. Give Rachel our best and let us know when we can come over.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Will do. Stuart shakes hands with Mitch and bump shoulders...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: See you at the office. Joe hugs him...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Congrat’s again, man. Can’t wait to meet her. Frank, Joe and Stuart walk away talking and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: And don’t think I’ve forgotten you owe me a Snicker’s bar. Mitch dials a cab. Then sees A PAIR OF GUYS admiring his parked Escalade. One of the Guys looks in the window.  10.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (can’t believe these guys) What the -- ? Mitch looks around. Frank, Stuart and Joe vanish around t corner.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Harvard Cabs. Mitch kills the call and walks toward his Escalade. Fearless. You can take the kid out of Dorchester, but you can’t take Dorchester out of the kid.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hey. He zaps his keys. The Escalade’s lights flash.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I help you guys with something? The Guys see Mitch and walk away. Mitch stands firm by hi car. Keys in one hand, phone in the other. What to do? He sees the Guys hanging at the street corner. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Screw this. Mitch opens the door and climbs in. Fires the engine. Thunder rumbles in the night sky as he drives away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain falls on the windshield. Mitch tuns on the wipers. H sees a COP CAR sitting at an intersection. Mitch drives p on a green light. Doesn’t look at them. He lifts the center arm rest and pulls out a tin of mints Pops a few in his mouth. Glances in the mirror as the lig change behind him and -- The Cop Car drives straight across the intersection and vanishes from sight. Mitch breathes a sigh of relief. Turns his attention back the road and -- BOOM! The Escalade hits a YOUNG MAN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT/EXT. MITCH’S ESCALADE - A SERIES OF SHOTS Mitch stomps the brake. Young Man is dragged underneath. Tires bite the wet road. Horrendous thuds as Young Man tumbles and brakes beneath undercarriage. The tires finally grip and -- The Escalade stops.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no.... Mitch stabs the seat-belt release and pushes open the doo Mitch staggers out into the rain and sees the crumpled me of a body lying fifteen feet behind the Escalade. Mitch runs to the Young Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch skids to a stop. Rain falls on the bloody body. Leg twisted at an impossible angle. Arms broken. Young Man blinks up at Mitch in the rain. Blood bubbling on his pal lips. Oil and blood matting his red hair. We recognize him from the opening park - CECIL ACKERMAN.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. I’m sorry. I’m so sorry. Mitch takes off his jacket and lays it over Cecil’s coatl and _shoeless body...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t move. I’m going to call an ambulance. Mitch runs back to the Escalade... INT. MITCH’S ESCALADE - NIGHT Mitch grabs his iPhone and fires up the screen. He is met a_photo of Rachel and his baby. He stops.  12. Looks back at Cecil lying in the rain. At the picture on his phone. Fuck. He sees a PAYPHONE at the corner of the street.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. PAYPHONE - DARBY STREET -— NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch grabs the handset, hand covered with a handkerchief Dials 911. Covers the mouthpiece with his other hand.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: 911 what’s your emergency?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I need an ambulance. There’s been an accident. Somebody was hit by a car.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s the location?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (looks around) Darby Street. South of 20th.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s your name, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Just hurry. He’s hurt real bad. Mitch slams down the phone. Wipes the buttons. Takes a de breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch runs back to Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: They're coming. You just hang on, you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (mumbles ) Help ... me...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Help is on its way. You’re going to be okay.  13. Mitch HEARS a_ sharp, metallic SNAP from a side alley and stares into the darkness. Is somebody there? Rain drums but nothing else moves. Finally, in the distance, Mitch HEARS the faint howl of a ambulance siren.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You hear that? They’re coming. I have to go now. Mitch grabs his jacket, but Cecil clings to it with his o good hand. Cecil’s eyes plead at him. He looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t stay. Mitch unpicks Cecil’s fingers from the now bloody jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a family. I can’t be involved. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Mitch pulls his jacket free and business cards fall out. Mitch quickly scrapes them out of the blood and rain. Cec stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to be okay. Mitch turns away. Runs back to his Escalade... INT. MITCH’S ESCALADE - NIGHT Mitch climbs in and slams the door. Puts his hand on the shifter. A deep breath...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. Jams it into drive...  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a spin of tires, the Escalade zooms forward and hang hard right out of the street. All is quiet save for the distant siren and the fall of rain on the blacktop. THE CAMERA lingers on Cecil. Helpless. Precious blood minglin with the rain. Fear in his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Streetlights whip hypnotic stripes across Mitch’s face. H sees an AMBULANCE zoom past. Lights flashing blood red. Mitch starts to gag. He pulls to the side of the road. Opens the door. Vomits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge soap-rollers spread foam over the Escalade. Scrub it clean. Mitch watches from beyond an observation window. INT. GARAGE —- THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch parks the Escalade next to Rachel’s Prius and climb out. The automatic garage door closes with a whir and a clunk. Mitch climbs out, shoves his coat into a garbage b kicks off his shoes and throws them in, too. He then unbuckles his pants and removes his shirt. He looks at th washer and dryer in the room. Decides against it... EXT. PATIO —- THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch carries the bag of clothes to the BBQ and removes t lid. He empties the clothes into the grill and squirts fl onto them. He strikes a match. Slings it onto the clothes They ignite. He stands there watching the fabric burn. Light flickering on his face... INT. BATHROOM — THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch showers. Lets the steaming, hot water wash him clea INT. BEDROOM —- THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch, in boxer shorts and a cotton T-shirt, looks at his sleeping wife, hand holding the edge of the baby’s bassin The baby is cocooned in a white blanket. Tiny. Helpless. Mitch climbs into bed beside Rachel. Wraps an arm around and kisses the back of her head. She moans but doesn’t wa Mitch just lies there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MITCH'’S ESCALADE (MOVING) - FLASHBACK Mitch hits Cecil. Boom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch wakes with a start. Warm, morning light filters through the window lace. Mitch rubs his face. Looks at th time. Its 7am. Rachel and the baby are gone. Mitch climbs from the bed... INT. BABY ROOM —- THE BRODY HOUSE - MORNING Rachel looks exhausted. She is pacing back and forth with the baby on her shoulder. Patting her back as the baby whimpers fitfully.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hey. You okay? Mitch kisses Rachel...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She'd had me up since four.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You want me to take her for a while?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, I need to change her. Why don’t you start the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch opens the front door and picks up the newspaper. He glances around the quiet street. A NEIGHBOR waves... INT. KITCHEN —- THE BRODY HOUSE — MORNING Mitch spoons coffee into the drip filter and zaps on the television. Flips between morning news shows.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mitch. She startles him. Rachel walks in from the garage carryin the baby and handful of clean diapers...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (tired and irritated) You want to tell me what happened last night?  16.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What -- ?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m talking about the truck. Mitch’s breath stops. Tries not to react...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You drove after promising you'd catch a cab. Mitch breathes...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get a DUI and you can kiss the DA's office goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You're right. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m serious. You’re a father now. You can’t take chances. The baby rubs her tiny face with a perfect little hand an lets out a squeak...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, Ella agrees with me.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (moved) Ella? (beat; reading her) You're sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes. But don’t change the subject. Mitch gives her a hug. This means a lot to him. Kisses he Kisses Ella...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Thank you. For everything. (beat) I don’t know what I’d do if I ever lost you guys.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Why would you lose us? The doorbell rings...  17.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That’1ll be Frau Strudel. You should get back into bed.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Her name is Schultze. Be nice. Rachel walks out and heads back up the stairs. Mitch look sad. Feels like shit. Takes a deep breath and heads to th front door... INT. GARAGE — THE BRODY HOUSE - MORNING The garage door rises with a CLUNK. Light spills slowly across the Escalade and Prius. Mitch stands there in a su carrying a coffee and his briefcase. He looks at the Escalade. Then climbs into the Prius. Reverses out of the garage... EXT. FEDERAL BUILDING —- MORNING Establishing shot... INT. MITCH’S OFFICE - DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE - MORNIN Mitch Googles: “Boston Hospitals”. An extremely short lis of names come up. He picks up his phone and dials...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mass General.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m with the DA’s office and I'm following up on a hit and run that was brought in last night.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just a second. Last night, you say. Mitch taps his pen nervously...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s nothing in admissions.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Around midnight. Caucasian male. Mid-twenties. Red hair. Mitch’s SECRETARY appears in the doorway. He raises a fin to her. She waits...  18.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sorry. You know, you could try Sinai - they sometimes get our spillover.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I will. Thank you. Mitch hangs up. Looks at Secretary...

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Staff meeting starts in five.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Right. Mitch stands. Gathers his files...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Could you do me a favor and call around the local hospitals and clinics. I’m trying to track down a young man who was involved in a hit and run accident last night.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Do you have a name?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No. Mitch walks past her...

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: What case is it connected to?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Just let me know if you find him. Secretary watches him walk toward the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: WITH MITCH
dialogues.text: as he walks toward the conference room. He takes a bottle Tylenol from his pocket. Stuart falls in beside him, drinking coffee...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: How’s the head? Mitch gives him a “not good” look.

dialogues.speaker: STUART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Man, I am so off Tequila.  19. Mitch stops at the water fountain. Stuart walks on. Mitch drinks the water and swallows the Tylenol. As he wipes hi mouth he sees --

dialogues.speaker: A PAIR OF UNIFORM COPS
dialogues.text: standing at reception. The RECEPTIONIST points toward Mit The COPS walk toward him. Mitch is riveted to the spot. The Cops approach, in seeming slow motion, removing their peaked caps and -- Mitch turns away. Walks into a Secretary carrying a tray coffee. Behind Mitch, the Cops are greeted by a different A.D.A. They walk into his office... INT. BATHROOM —- DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE — MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch runs water on a hand towel and dabs at the coffee o his shirt and tie. Takes a long, deep, calming breath. INT. DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE — MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch walks toward his office. Glances at the Cops talkin to the A.D.A. in his office. Nobody pays Mitch any attention. He really can breathe easy. Before Mitch enters his own office, Secretary looks up fr her work...

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I called everywhere and none of them admitted a hit and run last night. You want me to call outside the city?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Oh, and somebody named Doyle called. Wouldn’t leave his last name. Mitch stops. The name means something to him...  20. SECRETARY (CONT’D) He said to tell you he’s “out” and wants to see you. He left a contact number. Mitch takes the post-it from her. SECRETARY (CONT’D) You want me to get him on the phone for you?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No. I got it. Mitch goes into his office. Closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. KERRY’S CAFE - DAY An overweight DELIVERY DRIVER gets into his Fed-EX truck drives away. Mitch is sitting in a window seat of Kerry's Cafe. Grease and caffeine are all they sell... INT. KERRY’S CAFE — DAY Mitch sips a coffee and looks at DOYLE LOGAN, 30s, croppe hair, tattoo poking above the collar of his sweater, sitt opposite. Doyle chomps on a bacon sandwich. Moans with delight.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Bacon. I tell you, man, it’s the simple things you miss.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: So, how’ve you been?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (smiles; mouth full) How’ve I been? You mean apart from dating a guy called Bubba for most of the last decade and having “enter here” tattooed on my ass-— cheeks?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: I'm kidding, bro. I’m good. Never better.  21.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Are you clean?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Straight to the point. Eight years.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Listen...

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (knows what he’s going to say--) Don’t sweat it. I wouldn’t have come to see your ass either. Mitch breathes -- been let off the hook --

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got your card when da’ died, though. That was nice.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He was a good man.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: He was a drunken ass. Mitch laughs and nods. Doyle sees Mitch’s wedding band...

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got hitched.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Any kids?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: One. Ella.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: After your ma’.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: How old?  22.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (checks his watch) Two days, seven hours and thirteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: A newbie. Congratulations, pops. You got a picture? Mitch slides his iPhone across to Doyle. Rachel and Ella the screen-saver image.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice. And the baby’s cute, too. Mitch takes the phone back...

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’ve done real good for yourself, Mitch. I almost shit a brick when my parole officer said you worked for the D.A.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s early days.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Don’t do that. You made something of yourself. Be proud. Doyle raises his coffee cup in toast and sips...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Why, you offering? (beat; cracks a smile) They've got me crashing in some halfway house. It’s part of my reintegration program. You know - help me back into society. He digs through his pocket. Pulls out a scrap of paper...

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here it is. Cardiff Street. I wrote it down for you. Mitch takes the paper...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: How is it?  23.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Four walls and a roof. Anything's better than Popes Hill or the pen, you know what I’m saying? Doyle raises his cup and gestures for a refill.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: How are you fixed for money?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: They've set me up with a couple of interviews. I didn’t call to hit you up or nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That’s good because between student loans, mortgage payments and a new baby, I ain’t got shit.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Maybe I could spot you some. I’ve got a little stashed away. The bit da’ left me. Your ma’s government bonds.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: She wanted you to have them.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Christ, it’s good to see you, Mitch. It really is. You look great. Mitch smiles then sees the face of CECIL ACKERMAN appear the TV. He looks fresh faced and happy, but it’s definite him. Cecil’s photo is replaced by a MALE REPORTER outside Boston Police Station.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (to Waitress) Excuse me. Could you turn that up? Doyle looks from the TV back to Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: What is it? What’s going on? Waitress turns the sound up.  24.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: What started out as a routine traffic stop last night turned into a gruesome murder investigation when Boston PD Officers stopped this white van... We see a WHITE VAN through the chain-link fence. REPORTER (CONT’D) (uninterrupted) ..-parked here behind me in the police impound - for nothing more than a broken tail light. Camera comes back to Reporter... REPORTER (CONT’D) When officers, climbing from their vehicle, saw blood dripping from a rear door they demanded that the driver open the van. It was then that they discovered the body of Cecil Ackerman, a 24 year old parolee from Somerville. Mitch watches -- breath held -- REPORTER (CONT’D) Early reports are that the driver, who for now must remain nameless, claims his innocence. Saying that he found Ackerman dying in the road, the victim of an apparent hit and run, and was merely trying to get him to a hospital. Mitch pushes up to his feet --

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: This is Jeff Franklin, reporting live, from Back Bay.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Do you know that guy? Mitch digs out his wallet...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s ... it’s a work thing.  25.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Hey, if you’ve gotta go, you've gotta go. Mitch holds out a twenty. Doyle waves it off.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your money’s no good here.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’1l call you. Mitch walks away.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Let’s arrange a time for me to come meet my new family. Mitch? But Mitch just pushes out the street door. Doesn’t look back. Waitress tops up Doyle's coffee. Mitch’s departure stung Doyle, but he covers it with a smile...

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was my brother. He's a big shot D.A. He’s working an important case.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Waitress walks on. Doyle chomps on his bacon sandwich...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. POLICE STATION - BACK BAY — DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mitch pulls up to a meter in the Prius, he sees a pair NEWS VANS camped outside the station. Mitch climbs out an walks toward the station doors. Looks through the familia chain-link fence into the impound yard and sees the white van. INT. POLICE STATION —- BACK BAY —- DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch approaches the DESK SERGEANT. Shows him his ID...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Detective Kanon is expecting me. INT. DETECTIVE KANON’S OFFICE - POLICE STATION - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE BLAKE KANON, 48, hair tied back, is typing a re into her computer, glasses perched on the tip of her nose hunt-and-peck two finger typer.  26. Her office is a mess of paperwork. Shelves lined with baseball trophies. A signed photo of Kanon and Micky Mant hangs on the wall. She’s a woman in a man’s world. Mitch knocks on the open door.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Detective Kanon? Kanon gestures for him to come in and sit. She types a la couple of words and then --

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: How many tees in committed?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Two. Kanon fixes it, saves, and takes off her glasses...

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: Paperwork. Worst part of the job. Do you touch type?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I have a secretary. Kanon pops a Nicorette gum...

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: Nice. (offers him gum; he declines--) So, you got here quick. You said on the phone you were interested in the Ackerman murder.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: DA assigned just you?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: This is a provisional enquiry.

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: Walk with me. Kanon picks up a stack of papers. They leave the office..

dialogues.speaker: KANON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Suspect’s name is Tobias Levy. Forty-Nine years old. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KANON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Car mechanic by trade. Couple of assault charges, nothing he did time for. No relatives. Wife and daughter were both murdered a few years back.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It said on the news that he found Ackerman in the road.

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: We've had officers out there. No broken car parts, no blood that we can see...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It was raining pretty hard last night.

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: True -- but with the dead kid’s blood and hair on his clothes -- not to mention the bloody tools and plastic sheets we found in the back of the van -- we’ve got enough to charge him. You guys need to decide if it’s enough to convict. Mitch looks through a window and sees --

dialogues.speaker: TOBIAS LEVY
dialogues.text: sitting handcuffed in a chair in the middle of an intervi room. Levy is an unassuming man. Hair thin. His clothes taken as evidence. He is wrapped in a large blanket. Hand stained with dry blood.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He looks scared.

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: You think the guilty ones don’t? This guy’s staring down twenty to life for this one alone.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What do you mean “this one”?

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: I ran some keywords through the database -- tools, torture, male victims. It flagged a string of unsolved homicides. We’re pulling the files now.  28.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You think this guy’s a serial killer? You don’t even know he did this one.

dialogues.speaker: KANON
dialogues.text: Listen kid, I just work the evidence. Every detective here has a caseload this high -- and only 24 hours in the day to work ‘em -- so if it turns out this guy clears up five unsolveds -- that’s a good day in my books. Kanon starts to walks away...

dialogues.speaker: KANON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell your boss he'll get everything we've got when we get it, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What if he really is just a “Good Samaritan”? Did you consider that? Kanon just waves -- doesn’t look back. There is a commoti down the hall. A PRIEST is there arguing with OFFICERS.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Then let me talk to somebody in charge. Officers beckon to Kanon who sighs and approaches the Pri Mitch -- alone now -- steps closer to the window. Looks i on Levy who just sits there. Unmoving. Calm.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You must have made a mistake. Tobias wouldn’t hurt a fly. I’m not leaving until I see him. Mitch looks down the hall at the Priest and Kanon talking

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hasn’t he been through enough? Mitch looks back at Levy. We see Mitch’s reflection in th glass. Their faces line up over each other, like Mitch an Levy are interchangeable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. THE PAXTON TAP — AFTERNOON The place is quiet. A few early drinkers. Mitch is sittin at the bar nursing a beer. BARTENDER (GIO), 40, friendly, slides him a shot of Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Hair of the dog.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m not hungover. Mitch rubs his hand through his hair. Needs to talk...

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: So, why the face like a slapped ass? Bartender pops the cap off a Bud Lite and hands it toa customer. Writes on their tab...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Buddy of mine did something stupid and he doesn’t know how to fix it.

dialogues.speaker: GIO
dialogues.text: What are we talking - stupid stupid or illegal stupid?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Lose everything - career, wife, freedom - kinda stupid.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Does anybody else know your friend did this thing?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Then, shit man - whatever it is - tell him to say twelve Hail Marys and take it to the grave.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Somebody else is being blamed for what he did.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Ouch.  30.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He only has two choices, right? Fess up or let the guy take the rap. And either way he’s screwed. Mitch downs the Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Personally - and I’m an asshole - I'd still choose the Hail Marys and throw in a prayer that he doesn’t get a prosecutor like you.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: This may come as a surprise to you, Mitch, but some prosecutors lose cases from time to time. Somebody further along the bar signals to Bartender. He walks away... BARTENDER (CONT’D) Yes, pal? What can I do you for? Mitch sits there. The wheels of his mind turning. He gets up and throws a twenty on the bar. Hurries out the door..

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JONES’ OFFICE - DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE - EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D.A. JONES is at his desk working. There is a knock at th door. He looks up as Mitch enters...

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Mitch. I thought you’d left for the day.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I have a request, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the glass wall of Jones’ office we see Mitch maki his case. Eventually Jones nods. Mitch steps out of the office and breathes.  31. SOUND UPCUT - A HARSH BUZZER and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steel gate rolls back and clangs to a stop. Mitch and Stuart walk through passing GUARDS. The gate is rolled closed again behind them and SLAMS. Mitch flinches... INT. INTERVIEW ROOM —- CITY JAIL - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Stuart walk in. Levy is wearing a badly fitting prison jumpsuit. Wrists cuffed. Sitting beside him at the table is a wet-behind-the-ears PUBLIC DEFENDER - TERRY LUNDGREN. Lundgren stands to great them. They trade business cards...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Mitch Brody, D.A.'s office. This is my associate Stuart Kemp.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Terry Lundgren, Public Defenders office. Mitch looks at Lundgren’s card. A printed name has been crossed out and Lundgren’s name written in by hand. He’s that new.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I haven’t got my own cards yet. Mitch and Stuart take seats across the table. Take files from their briefcases. Levy just stares at Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Mister Levy, we’re going to ask you a few questions about the night of the 4th. If you could answer as clearly and accurately as possible.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Are you my prosecutor?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: I’m innocent. Levy hold’s Mitch's look.  32.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Then you’ve got nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Do I have your word on that, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Levy sits back...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Can you tell us where you were earlier that night, Mr. Levy? Were you out drinking?

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: I don’t drink. I finished work, went to group, then I went for a drive. Mitch notices Lundgren write that down. out of ink.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Group? Mitch slides Lundgren a pen.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Or try. His pen is I help out at support groups and church meetings.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I see. And the drive?

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Just something I do. Helps me sleep. Haven’t you ever taken a drive at night, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That's beside the point. I’m not the one under arrest for murder. Again Mitch feels Levy hold his gaze. Uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Right. It’s penetrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. JONES’ OFFICE —- DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE -— DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Stuart are sitting opposite Jones.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: What do we know about the victim?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Cecil Ackerman. Mitch hands Jones a rap sheet with a photo of Ackerman on

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A registered sex offender. Two counts of statutory rape. Been out on parole for three months.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: So, a real loss to humanity.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: So far, there’s no connection between him and Levy.

dialogues.speaker: STAURT
dialogues.text: Other than Levy’s hammer in the back of his head, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Tell me about the murder weapon.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Weapons. Plural. Coroner couldn’t be exact but the wounds are consistent with the type of tools and machine parts found in the back of Levy’s van.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Though they also found significant amounts of motor oil and grit in the wounds which corroborates his hit and run story.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: True, but the vic’s DNA and blood were all over Levy’s clothes -- inside his van...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: All of which is explainable by transference when he lifted Ackerman into his van.  34.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Or when he murdered him.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: BAM! Mitch's Escalade hits Ackerman.

dialogues.speaker: STUART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Levy has three counts of aggravated assault.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: At a time when his family had just been murdered in a home invasion. He hasn’t had so much as a parking ticket since.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: That doesn’t negate the fact that he took a tire-iron to three men and hospitalized them.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: What’s concerning you, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I don’t see motive.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Ackerman was a pedophile.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Levy’s daughter was murdered, not raped. It doesn’t fit. Secretary knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Terry Lundgren just called. There was a 911 call. Tape’s on its way. Mitch looks worried... INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretary slots the cassette into the machine. Mitch and Stuart sit opposite Jones.  35.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Somebody called in an accident twenty minutes before Levy was picked up. When the ambulance got there ... there was no body.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Let’s hear it. Secretary presses play. Static fills the room. We can fee Mitch stop breathing as --

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: 911 what’s your emergency? MITCH'’S VOICE (0.S.) There’s been an accident. Mitch watches the room for any hint of recognition...

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s the location? MITCH’S VOICE (0.S.) It’s Darby Street. Just south of 20th. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s your name, sir? MITCH’S VOICE (0.S.) Please hurry. He’s hurt real bad. There is a click and the call ends. Secretary presses sto

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: You want me to play it again?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: The location matches Levy’s story but we can’t rule out the possibility that he made the call himself.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Is there any way we can find the caller?  36.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He used a payphone. Stuart looks up from documents that came with the tape.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Because we'd have the man’s name if it wasn’t. Mitch breathes...

dialogues.speaker: JONES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, the tape’s potentially damaging but not conclusive. Maybe it was a crank, maybe not, but if we can’t find the caller then defense can’t. Hell, it could be anyone in Boston. It sounds like Mitch. Where were you that night? Stuart and Secretary laugh. Mitch smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JONES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bottom line. Do we have enough for a conviction?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Without motive? I say no.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Stuart?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Levy was caught - pardon the pun - red-handed. We have physical evidence, a documented history of violence, no alibi, and his public defender is the kind of guy Mitch eats for breakfast. Jones weighs a decision. To prosecute or not to prosecute Mitch says a silent prayer and --

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Charge him. Murder one. Mitch’s shoulders sink. Jones gets up and leaves. Stuart and Secretary gather papers and the tape. Stuart pats his shoulder...  37.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: You've got to have more faith in yourself, buddy. Mitch is left alone. He just sits there...

dialogues.speaker: BOSTON MUNICIPAL COURTHOUSE
dialogues.text: Establishing. A crisp day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Stuart take their seats. Mitch looks at Lundgre and Levy at the next table. The jury is already seated. Mitch flexes his hands. Tense. A door opens and Judge McKenna walks in and goes to her s

dialogues.speaker: COURT BAILIFF
dialogues.text: All rise. Mitch and the rest of the room stand. Judge McKenna sits straightens her papers. COURT BAILIFF (CONT’D) Court is now in session. The Honorable Judge McKenna presiding.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Be seated. Are counsel for the prosecution and defense both present?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: We are your honor. Judge makes a note...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: In the case of the people versus Tobias Levy, your client entered a plea of not guilty. Does he wish to change that plea here today?

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: He does not, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Very well. Defense may go ahead with its opening statement.  38.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Thank you, your honor. This case is nothing more than a huge misinterpretation of the facts...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Not to me, Mr. Lundgren. To them. Judge McKenna indicates the Jury. Lundgren turns to them. Stuart smiles. Mitch exhales... throwing this case is goi to be harder than he thought.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. COURTROOM — COURTHOUSE - AFTERNOON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is low outside the windows. The CORONER is on the stand. There are blow-up photos of tools from the back of Levy's van on display...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You examined the body, Doctor. In your professional opinion what was the cause of death?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Blunt force trauma to the skull.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Do you know what caused that trauma?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: The back of the skull was badly crushed so its hard to narrow it down to any one item but some of the marks seem consistent with a hammer found in the suspect’s van.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You said “seem” consistent.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: That’s correct.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your report talks of abrasions and impact wounds with motor oil and grease in them. The defence, I’m sure, is going to argue that those wounds indicate a car ran Cecil Ackerman over and that the rest is a misinterpretation of the evidence.  39.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: The accused is a mechanic who used his van to transport old parts to and from the wrecker’s yard. If I remember correctly there was an axle, leaf springs, suspension arms inside... And the interior was covered in grease and motor oil. So any type of violent struggle in that environment could have caused those wounds and left that trace evidence.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I see. And did you identify any of those parts as things he used?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: There was blood on a lot of things - - it might be easier to say which one’s he didn’t use. This gets a reaction from the jury. They look at Levy. Disgusted. Like he’s a monster. Mitch breathes. He’s not swayed the Jury one inch...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No further questions, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DINING ROOM —- MITCH’S HOME — NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch has the entire case spread over the table in front him. He sips a coffee and rubs his eyes. Rachel walks in carrying Ella.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Bit late for coffee, isn’t it? She looks over his shoulder. Sees a photo of Tobias Levy years younger than the man we know - happier...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Four years ago. This is before his family were murdered in a home invasion. He was forced to watch and then left for dead. Mitch pulls out a picture of Levy with his wife and daugh  40.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That's horrible. Did they catch the killer?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He was gunned down in another home invasion the next night.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Is that what made his snap?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That’s the general consensus. Mitch sips his coffee...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Here, I know you’re working, but can you take Ella for a bit? I need to take a shower before bed. I smell like milk and my hair feels like straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel hands him Ella. He cradles her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Does mommy smell like milk because of you? Does she? Ella's eyes sparkle as she looks up at him. She grips his finger with her tiny hand. Mitch takes a big sigh. This little life is why he’s doing everything he’s doing... MITCH’S VOICE (0.S.) It’s Darby Street, just south of 20th. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch is listening as the tape is played over speakers fo the Jury...

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s your name, Sir? MITCH’S VOICE (0.S.) Please hurry. He’s hurt real bad. The call ends. Everyone looks to -- DR. EVELYN BROWN, 50s, professional, blind since birth, w is sitting, calmly on the stand.  41.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Your witness, Mr. Brody. Stuart leans in to Mitch...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Piece of cake. The jury has no idea what she’s been talking about. Mitch takes that onboard and --

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m not very familiar with your field, Dr. Brown and I’m sure neither is the jury. Brown looks toward Mitch. Even behind her black glasses w sense her staring at him with some sense of recognition.. It gives Mitch pause. He coughs...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just how accurate is forensic linguistics?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BROWN
dialogues.text: Extremely. Mitch stands. Begins to pace.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: But not perfect.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BROWN
dialogues.text: Perfection doesn’t happen in science. Her head follows him as he moves. Listening...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: On a sliding scale of one to ten then?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: (to Lundgren) You might want to object, counselor. The witness’ field is not on trial here. Before Lundgren can respond...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I'll withdraw the question, your honor. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You stated earlier that the caller was genuine - and by that I assume you mean he was reporting a real accident.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BROWN
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: And you can tell this just by listening to his voice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BROWN
dialogues.text: It’s more complicated than that, but - yes.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Can you tell us anything else about the caller?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BROWN
dialogues.text: Probably white. Medium build. He’s from the south of Boston, but he’s tried hard to soften the accent - again, not unlike yourself counselor. You’re from where - Dorchester?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BROWN
dialogues.text: The caller had a strict Roman Catholic upbringing - so there’s probably Irish in there - which we can tell by an almost inaudible prayer he mumbles while the operator is talking. I’m sure he didn’t even know he did it himself. And he’s cool under pressure which we know from the way he gives no personal details and had the forethought to use a payphone even in his heightened emotional state. All of which tells me he has either a legal or criminal background. None of which matches Tobias Levy.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Legal or criminal. That’s quite a spread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, the psychological traits for both professions are surprisingly similar.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: So, in your professional opinion is it even in the realm of possibility that Tobias Levy made this 911 call himself - to establish an alibi?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BROWN
dialogues.text: No. It is not. 43. The Jury trades nods of understanding. Stuart drops his p on the desk. No idea what’s going on. Judge McKenna just stares at Mitch. INT. MCKENNA’S CHAMBERS - COURTHOUSE —- AFTERNOON

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Judge McKenna hangs her gown and goes to sit behind her d as Mitch and Lundgren enter.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Shut the door. Lundgren closes it. JUDGE MCKENNA (CONT’D) Okay, what the hell is going on out there?

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Your honor, I...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: I’m not talking to you, Mr. Lundgren. The way you're going, your client will be lucky if he isn’t put away for life. But I guess you were sick they day DeVry taught cross examination. Lundgren shuts up. JUDGE MCKENNA (CONT’D) I'm waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to get to the truth, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Don't bullshit a bullshitter, Mr. Brody. You practically made the defense’s case for them with that last witness.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That wasn’t my intention.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: What was?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I thought I could shake her credibility. McKenna stares at him. A beat...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: I’m going to say this once, and once only. If I sense anybody isn’t playing straight on this I will call for a mistrial and start the whole thing over. Do you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Yes, your honor. But Judge McKenna is still looking at Mitch...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Get out of my sight. INT. HALLWAY — COURTHOUSE - EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Lundgren part ways. Mitch strides along the hallway. Glances at -- Dr. Brown talking to Det. Kanon. Kanon watches Mitch. Mit feels under the microscope... EXT. PARKING LOT —- COURTHOUSE - EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch puts the key in the Prius door and A HAND spins him around. Mitch throws his hands up. It’s Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What are you doing? You scared the crap out of me.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You should be scared. (beat) I was in there. I heard the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch is sitting in a booth with Doyle. Both have beers..

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I didn’t know what else to do. I'd been drinking. I panicked.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You’ve got a lot to lose.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That’s no excuse. I should have stayed.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: But you didn’t. And I don’t blame you. But what the ef’ were you thinking taking the case?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I couldn't let somebody else prosecute. There are ADAs in my office who were ready to crucify him. The evidence is so ambiguous you can paint any story you want onto it -- he’d be railroaded.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: He would with this public defender.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I thought I could just ease back and let the guy win but this idiot couldn’t try his way out of a paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: So, let him go down. You don’t owe this schmuck anything.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He’s innocent.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Pen’s full of innocent men. He’1l fit right in.  46.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m not joking, Doyle. A man’s life is at stake here.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: So, throw the case.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’ve been trying. Now the judge is watching me like a hawk. I’m screwed. (a long beat) I think I’m going to have to confess.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: That’s just stupid.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m out of options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch walks in from the garage. His iPhone rings. He puts down his briefcase and answers it...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hello. KANON’S VOICE (0.S.) Hey, Brody, it’s Kanon.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (rubs his eyes) Detective Kanon. What can I do for you? KANON’S VOICE (0.S.) Just checking in. We lost a point or two on that forensic linguist.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: She gave compelling testimony. KANON’S VOICE (0.S.) Right. Mitch gets a knot in his stomach...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s late, Detective. Is there something you need?  47. KANON’S VOICE (0.S.) No. Just wanted to know that you're ready for tomorrow. Mitch HEARS a BEEP on the line...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What was that? KANON’S VOICE (0.S.) What?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Are you recording me? KANON’S VOICE (0.S.) Why would I be recording you? (beat) Lawyers. And they say cops are paranoid. See you in court. Click. The line goes dead. Mitch feels very uneasy. He hangs up. Looks up the stairs... INT. BEDROOM —- THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch looks down on Ella. So tiny ... so vulnerable. She whimpers in her sleep. Mitch picks her up. Sees Rachel, i the bed, open her eyes and start to rise. On exhausted au pilot...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Go back to sleep, babe. I’ve got her. Rachel flops back down. Takes a big tired sigh. Mitch crosses to the window and looks out at the neighborhood. the stars in the sky. The stillness of it all. Thinking..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is rising. INT. KITCHEN — MITCH’S HOUSE - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That same house-rattling CLUNK from the garage door. Thro the window we see Mitch reversing out. He pauses in the driveway. A sad look on his face. Then drives away. THE CAMERA moves away from the window to the coffee pot where A NOTE sits with two words written on it: “I’m sorry.”  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch walks toward main doors like a man walking to the gallows. He glances at a car parked by the curb. Sees DR. BROWN being helped out of the passenger side. Mitch passes KANON standing by the doors, drawing on a cigarette. Mitch nods to her. Enters the building... INT. MEN'S BATHROOM — COURTHOUSE - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch scoops a handful of water from the faucet. Drinks i Fixes his tie. He can do this. INT. COURTROOM — COURTHOUSE - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch takes his seat beside Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hey, champ. You look like you didn't sleep a wink.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’ve got a lot on my mind. Mitch looks across at Levy. Alone. Lundgren isn’t here ye Levy looks back. Mitch turns away.

dialogues.speaker: COURT BAILIFF
dialogues.text: All rise. Judge McKenna enters and takes her seat. The rest of the court retakes their seats. Mitch remains standing...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your honor, before session begins, I'd like to approach the bench. Suddenly the door opens and Lundgren hurries in clutching pile of files and papers.

dialogues.speaker: MCKENNA
dialogues.text: I won’t tolerate tardiness, Mr. Lundgren.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, your honor, but there’s been an important development. Defense would like to call a new witness.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Objection, you honor. Prosecution wasn’t informed of this.  49.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Defense wasn’t aware of their identity until late last night.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: What’s the relevance of this witness, Mr. Lundgren?

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: He’s the man who made the 911 call, your honor. Mitch’s world crushes in...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Again, your honor, we object. Without an opportunity to validate the claims of --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: I understand the objection.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Dr. Brown’s lab ran voice analysis overnight and we got a 96% match. Mitch can barely breathe. His window to confess is closin fast...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: How soon can defense present this witness?

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Right now, your honor. He’s been in this courtroom the entire trial. There is a scraping of chairs and people look around the room. Voices mumble and chatter at once. McKenna bangs he gavel...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Order.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your honor...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: I’m inclined to allow it, Mr. Brody.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I understand but, if I could just say something...  50.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: My mind is made up!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Please, I just -- Judge McKenna BANGS her gavel hard. Cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Enough! (to Lundgren) Call your witness.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: The defense calls -- Mitch closes his eyes, holds his breath and --

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Doyle Logan to the stand. Mitch opens his eyes and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: rises from a seat at the back of the court and walks forw Mitch stares at him. Doyle refuses to make eye contact... Doyle climbs up to the witness stand. COURT BAILIFF holds bible out before him...

dialogues.speaker: COURT BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (hand on the Bible) I do. Doyle takes his seat. Mitch sits. Lundgren walks forward.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Mr. Logan... Doyle leans into the mic and softens his Boston accent a little - like Mitch...

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Call me Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a surprise twist of events, a witness came forward today and ended the prosecution’s case against Tobias Levy.

dialogues.speaker: A CAMERA IMAGE
dialogues.text: Of a REPORTER standing outside the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: The witness saw the victim Cecil Ackerman mowed down in the rain by a hit and run driver, in a red Ford Explorer, and left in the road to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courthouse is emptying. The trial over. 51.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THE PRESS are gathered before Lundgren on the steps. From the way he ho himself you’d think he won the case on his legal skills..

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: (to the reporters) It seems that Tobias Levy was not the only Good Samaritan in this trial. Despite Mr. Logan’s initial reluctance to get involved, due to being out on parole, he finally put his own comfort aside and did the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: What about the wounds on the body?

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: The prosecution’s case was founded entirely on a gross misinterpretation of the forensic evidence. Mitch sees Levy standing to one side. Away from the limelight. Mitch approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Mr. Levy. I just wanted to congratulate you and wish you all the best. They shake hands...  52.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: You told me if I was innocent I’d have nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. Levy pinches the filter off a cigarette and drops it onto steps. He lights the rest of it with his Zippo.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: What happens now?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You go back to your life. Levy SNAPS the Zippo closed again. Something about the lighter draws Mitch’s attention...

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: I mean the hit and run driver. The one the witness saw. Levy pockets the Zippo.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Who knows. Maybe he’1ll come forward.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Would you? Levy smiles. It was a joke. Mitch walks away. Kanon was watching the whole interaction.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. BOSTON HARBOR —- MORNING The Provincetown II passenger ferry cuts a steady path ac the bay. The Boston downtown skyline in the background...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle stands at the rail with a coffee, looking out at th city. Mitch approaches and stands beside him.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You smell that? That’s the smell of freedom.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You took a huge risk taking that test for me.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: We grew up in the same house. Went to the same schools. Same friends. Same church. How hard could it be? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to do it.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Is it really that hard for you to say thank you?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m not used to relying on anyone else to get me out of a jam.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Well, you’re welcome. A beat. There’s a question building inside Mitch. He has ask...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Why did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You're my brother.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I mean, ten years ago. Why did you do that to me?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: I was stupid. I’ve had a lot of time to think about my life and who I was, and I let you down. (sincere) I won’t let you down again.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I won’t let you.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: I was doing a lot of drugs back then. I wasn’t thinking of anyone but myself.  54.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’d only worked at that warehouse two months. I begged you not to hit that payroll. I could have been done as an accessory.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: But you weren’t. I made sure of that. I kept your name out of it.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: My name shouldn’t have been in it in the first place! (beat) You know that night guard never walked again?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: It got out of hand.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It always does with you. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, what you did today means we can’t have contact for a while.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Like that matters to you.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: I called your house the other day, you know, looking for you. Mitch stops. Looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your wife - she doesn’t know who I am, does she?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You've been gone a long time.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: How could you not tell her about your own brother--?  55.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (cuts him off--) Stepbrother. (Doyle looks at him) And let’s face it, legally not even that.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Oh, you to play it like that. Doyle looks away. It was the worst thing Mitch could say him. Doyle tries to tough it out...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I met her when I was graduating. She processed my application form to the D.A.’s office. And seeing as my ma’ never officially married your da’ --

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You figured why mention us.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It was better for me not to have ties to a criminal past -- and once I'd lied on the forms, I couldn't very well tell her something different...

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: I understand. Doyle pushes away from the rail.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m not that kid anymore, Doyle. Dorchester was another life.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You're lucky. I only got the one. Doyle disappears inside the cabin. Mitch looks out at the city. Alone. Curses under his breath...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. KITCHEN —- THE BRODY HOUSE - EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch pours himself a Scotch. Drinks it. Takes a big sigh of relief. Pours another. Rachel walks in pulling a small towel from her shoulder. She puts a baby-monitor on the counter.  56.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hey. She wraps her tired arms around him. Buries her head into his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hey. How’s Ella?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Demanding. She only stopped crying ten minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You smell like milk.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Ella was sick on me.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: This is my third shirt today. How do people do it?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’ll get easier. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about the trial.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s fine. It’s - good - actually.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: The guy didn’t do it. So, this is a good day for justice.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Does Jones see it that way?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Of course not. I lost the case.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Talking of sorry. JI found your note.  57. Mitch looks at her. What is she -- ? Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Right. The note.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’ve just been ... tense ... and haven’t helped around here as much as I should and ... I’m sorry. Mitch kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (suggestive) Oh? He kisses her again.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry. He kisses her deeper.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Really, really... Ella starts to cry. Rachel moans. Tired. Pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I'll take a raincheck on that apology. Rachel heads back out of the kitchen. Mitch downs his Scotch. INT. GARAGE -— NIGHT Mitch puts another few pieces of the crib together. He ru sand paper over a joint. Feels it with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. SHOPPING MALL — DAY Establishing. Thousands of cars line the parking lot. The mall offers everything from Macy’s to ice-skating.  58. INT. BABY SECTION - MACY’S - DAY Rachel and Mitch are shopping for baby clothes. Rachel ta with a SALES ASSISTANT about sizes etc. Mitch sees other bored dads. Trades sympathetic nods with one.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hey, Rach’, I’m going to get a soda. You want anything?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Diet Coke. Mitch walks away. INT. FOOD COURT - SECOND FLOOR - SHOPPING MALL —- DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch pays for two sodas. As he collects straws he looks around the sea of hungry shoppers hunched over burgers, p slices and MSG laced cuisine and sees --

dialogues.speaker: TOBIAS LEVY
dialogues.text: sitting at a table near the railing. Looking down on the CENTRAL COURTYARD below. Mitch ducks behind a pillar. Doesn’t want to talk to him. Mitch looks out. Levy, face partially obscured by a baseb cap, is intensely focused on something below. Mitch follo his glare down to --

dialogues.speaker: A HISPANIC COUPLE
dialogues.text: Who are arguing. The man, VICTOR GONZALES, 35, slaps his wife across the face. Other shoppers react. A PAIR OF SECURITY GUARDS walk over and Victor swells his chest. We see the tattoos on his arms and neck. He challenges them in Spanish. Then spits and walks away... Mitch looks back at Levy, but his seat is empty. Mitch st out and scans the area. Finally he sees Levy riding the escalator down a level.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. PARK -— MORNING Mitch jogs. Runs by the lake. Pushing himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL’S WHOLE FAMILY is sitting at a long table eating f and talking. MOM, DAD, SISTERS, HUSBANDS. Wine and soda a flowing. Mom coos over Ella while Rachel gets to eat uninterrupted for once. Mitch watches them all. A little sad... INT. HOME OFFICE —- THE BRODY HOUSE - EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of Rachel’s family laughing in another room. Sounds like charades. Mitch picks a photo frame off his desk. Inside is a picture of himself as a small boy, standing with his mom. He opens the back of the frame and takes out the photo. We see it was folded in half. In the other half is a man holding another boy. He’s Mitch's age It’s Doyle...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MITCH’S OFFICE - DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch is at his desk. A pile of files and paperwork waiti to be gotten to. Mitch writes notes. INT. KITCHEN —- DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch walks in with his cup. A couple of secretaries are taking a break. Mitch glances at the newspaper one is reading. Stops in his tracks. He tilts his head to get a better look at the photo of -- Victor Gonzales, the Hispanic man from the mall...

dialogues.speaker: AN INTERNET NEWS BROADCAST
dialogues.text: a body is being lifted from the river. Police boats. Cops on the shore.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS BROADCASTER
